dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, have you been following the Shopify story lately? I mean, wow. Their demand for online tools has just absolutely skyrocketed, especially, uh, with everything going on.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, have you been following the Shopify story lately? I mean, wow. Their demand for online tools has just absolutely skyrocketed, especially, uh, with everything going on.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thanks to skyrocketing demand for its online business-building tools, the Ottawa-based e-commerce giant has brought a windfall to its public market investors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, totally! I saw that, um, it briefly became Canada's most valuable company. And Tobias Lutke, the CEO, is like, north of six billion dollars now. Wild, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, totally! I saw that, um, it briefly became Canada's most valuable company. And Tobias Lutke, the C E O, is like, north of six billion dollars now. Wild, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its value peaked at $84 billion last week, briefly making it the most valuable company in Canada, and pushing the net worth of its 39-year-old CEO Tobias Lutke north of $6 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? But here’s the kicker, though. For one of their earliest investors, this San Francisco firm called Bessemer Venture Partners, it's apparently, uh, really bittersweet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? But here's the kicker, though. For one of their earliest investors, this San Francisco firm called Bessemer Venture Partners, it's apparently, uh, really bittersweet.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But for one of its earliest investors, San Francisco-based Bessemer Venture Partners, the hype around the company is bittersweet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, I remember hearing about that. They put in, what was it, like 5.5 million initially? And then built up to a 26% stake when Shopify went public in 2015. That was worth 500 million back then.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, I remember hearing about that. They put in, what was it, like five point five million initially? And then built up to a twenty six percent stake when Shopify went public in twenty fifteen. That was worth five hundred million back then.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The firm first invested $5.5 million in the companys initial funding round, and after additional investments built a 26% stake worth $500 million when it went public in 2015.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But, um, as is typical for VCs, they started redistributing those shares back to their partners by the end of 2018. When Shopify was worth, like, 15 billion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. But, um, as is typical for V Cs, they started redistributing those shares back to their partners by the end of twenty eighteen. When Shopify was worth, like, fifteen billion.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though as is the typical modus operandi of venture capital firms hold onto investments while the company scales and cash out following an IPO Bessemer had redistributed all its shares back to its partners by the end of 2018, when the company was worth $15 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] Yeah, and that's the thing! Because today, that *same* stake, uh, would be worth close to twenty-two billion dollars.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that's the thing! Because today, that same stake, uh, would be worth close to twenty-two billion dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Today Bessemers stake would currently be worth close to $22 billion, the firm says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Twenty-two billion! Can you even imagine? They basically left, what was it, 17 billion dollars on the table by exiting when they did.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Twenty-two billion! Can you even imagine? They basically left, what was it, seventeen billion dollars on the table by exiting when they did.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By exiting Shopify two years ago, Bessemer left at least $17 billion on the table.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's just insane. So, like, why would they *do* that? I mean, I know there are pressures on venture capital firms to post returns within a certain timeframe, like five to ten years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's just insane. So, like, why would they do that? I mean, I know there are pressures on venture capital firms to post returns within a certain timeframe, like five to ten years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Venture capital funds are typically under pressure to post returns on investments in private startups over a relatively short period of time, between five and 10 years, says Gornal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly. They often sell shares back to their own investors, like pension funds, giving them the option to, uh, hold or cash out. It’s not really set up for those *massive* long-term Amazon or Google type returns.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly. They often sell shares back to their own investors, like pension funds, giving them the option to, uh, hold or cash out. It's not really set up for those massive long-term Amazon or Google type returns.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Once a company goes public, a venture firm will often sell its shares back to its own investors, which include pension funds and university endowments, giving them the option to hold their stake in the company or cash out. This kind of mission isnt conducive to reaping bigger returns that come years after a public offering, like those generated by other tech giants such as Amazon and Google.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But still, 17 billion? That’s not just a typical, like, "we cashed out too early" story. I mean, one of their own partners, Alex Ferrara, admitted he couldn’t comprehend they’d have *this* much success.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But still, seventeen billion? That's not just a typical, like, we cashed out too early story. I mean, one of their own partners, Alex Ferrara, admitted he couldn't comprehend they'd have this much success.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I couldnt comprehend that they would have this massive amount of success at that time, says Alex Ferrara, the Bessemer partner who led Shopifys initial funding round in 2010.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] Totally. And a professor from UBC said it was a 'significant missed opportunity' specifically because they had built such a large stake. Usually VCs don't hold that much.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And a professor from U B C said it was a significant missed opportunity specifically because they had built such a large stake. Usually V Cs don't hold that much.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Even though a global pandemic does not factor into the forecast of most investors, Bessemers stake in Shopify stands out as a significant missed opportunity in venture investing because it is rare that a venture capital firm would have built such a large stake in a hot startup, says Will Gornal, a professor at the University of British Columbias Sauder Business School.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And it’s only been supercharged by the pandemic, right? All those brick-and-mortar stores being forced online. Shopify just blew up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's only been supercharged by the pandemic, right? All those brick-and-mortar stores being forced online. Shopify just blew up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the past month, Shopifys share price has doubled after it generated $470 million in revenue in the first quarter, as demand for its online tools has skyrocketed from brick-and-mortar retailers who have been forced online by the COVID-19 pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. It really highlights how much the landscape shifted. I mean, Zoom's another one, quadrupled in value, now worth 44 billion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. It really highlights how much the landscape shifted. I mean, Zoom's another one, quadrupled in value, now worth forty four billion.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After going public last year, the San Jose-based firm is now worth $44 billion, almost triple its value at the start of the year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's just a crazy time for tech. But Bessemer, I guess, they're not totally alone. Felicis Ventures, another early investor, also redistributed their shares.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's just a crazy time for tech. But Bessemer, I guess, they're not totally alone. Felicis Ventures, another early investor, also redistributed their shares.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But Bessemer is not alone among early investors in Shopify for exiting the company before the height of its riches were truly clear. Felicis Ventures, which invested alongside Bessemer in 2010, has since redistributed its shares back to its limited partners, the firm says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: True, true. And Bessemer *did* get between 80 to 100 times their initial investment. So, y’know, not a total loss. As Ferrara said, 'We didn't have a crystal ball.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, true. And Bessemer did get between eighty to one hundred times their initial investment. So, y'know, not a total loss. As Ferrara said, We didn't have a crystal ball.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While Bessemers one-time stake in Shopify might prove a once-in-a-lifetime type tech position, Ferrara says the firm will gladly take its realized returns on the deal: between 80x and 100x its initial investment. Says the venture capitalist: We didnt have a crystal ball.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, 'no crystal ball.' But still, a pretty, uh, expensive lesson in patience, I guess. What a wild ride for Shopify, though.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, no crystal ball. But still, a pretty, uh, expensive lesson in patience, I guess. What a wild ride for Shopify, though.
